name: gold refinery operation | gold | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/19888/documentation

This dataset is a copy of the South African dataset for the production of refined gold and it is also used as the best available representation of the GLO situation of the sector as well.;This dataset describe the refinery of gold. Unrefined gold (85% gold) is upgraded to the London Good Delivery Standard (99.5% gold). A small percentage is further upgrade to the Jewellery standard (99.8% gold).

The activity start with the unrefined gold coming from both South African and non South African mines. Some gold is also recovered from scrap metals as secondary refinery.

The activity end with the refined gold sold both to the export and local market.
category: B:Mining and quarrying/07:Mining of metal ores/072:Mining of non-ferrous metal ores/0729:Mining of other non-ferrous metal ores

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: This dataset is a copy of the South African dataset for the production of refined gold and it is also used as the best available representation of the GLO situation of the sector as well. Figure below provide the overview top gold producer globally (source: www.focus-economics.org).;Rand Refinery (Pty) Limited is the largest integrated single-site precious metals refining and smelting complex in the world. Rand Refinery is the refining hub for Africa and increasingly beyond. It was established in 1920 to refine gold within South Africa which until that time had been refined in London. Since its inception it has refined nearly 50,000 tonnes of gold.[1] This represents some 30% of all the gold mined in the world since antiquity.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: REFINING: The refinery, which provides a same day refining service, employs the widely used Miller Chlorination Process to upgrade the gold bullion it receives from mines to at least 99.50% fine gold, the minimum standard required for gold sold on the world bullion markets. It also employs the world’s leading silver refining technology. To further refine gold and silver to 99.99% the cost-effective once-through Wohlwill electrolytic refining process is used.;MILLER CHLORINATION PROCESS: This is a pyrometallurgical process whereby gold dore is heated in furnace crucibles. The process is able to separate gold from impurities by using chlorine gas which is added to the crucibles once the gold is molten. Chlorine gas does not react with gold but will combine with silver and base metals to form chlorides. Once the chlorides have formed they float to the surface as slag or escape as volatile gases. The surface melt and the fumes containing the impurities are collected and further refined to extract the gold and silver. ;This process can take up to 90 minutes produces gold which is at least 99.5% pure with silver being the main remaining component. This gold can be cast into bars as 99.5% gold purity meets the minimum London Good Delivery. However some customers such as jewellers and other industrial end users require gold that is almost 100% pure, so further refining is necessary. In this case, gold using the Miller process is cast into anodes which are then sent to an electrolytic plant. The final product is 99.99% pure gold sponge that can then be melted to produce various end products suited to the needs of the customer.;WOHLWILL PROCESS - The electrolytic method of gold refining was first developed by Dr. Emil Wohlwill of Norddeutsche Affinerie in Hamburg in 1874. Dr. Wohlwill’s process is based on the solubility of gold but the insolubility of silver in an electrolyte solution of gold chloride (AuCl3) in hydrochloric acid. Figure below provide the overview of the refining process (source Rand Refinery Brochure);Emissions includes also HCl to air: 7.48e-03 Calculated from rand refinery scrubber and baghouse emmission values Metal concentrators, Emmision report 2016 http://www.environmentalconsultants.co.za/wp-content/uploads/2016/11/Appendix-D1.pdf
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Randy Refinery integrated report 2017 and private communication. Values obtained from personal communication with Rand refinery and from Randy Refinery Corporate Brochure 2017.  Emissions were calculated using the following references:                                                      Air Emission calculated  from rand refinery scrubber and baghouse emmission values Metal concentrators, Emmision report 2016 http://www.environmentalconsultants.co.za/wp-content/uploads/2016/11/Appendix-D1.pdf or calculated based on EU metal mining air emmisions Best Available Techniques Reference http://eippcb.jrc.ec.europa.eu/reference/                                                  Water emission calculated based on Authorized levels of deleterious substances prescribed in South African Water Quality Guidelines http://www.dwa.gov.za/iwqs/wq_guide/Pol_saWQguideFRESHAquaticecosystemsvol7.pdf or calculated based on EU metal mining liquid effluent regulations and guidelines for mining Best Available Techniques Reference http://eippcb.jrc.ec.europa.eu/reference/
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: This dataset is a copy of the South African dataset for the production of refined gold and it is also used as the best available representation of the GLO situation of the sector as well. Data were taken from Rand Refinery integrated report 2017 and private communication.

exchanges.description: Gold for the London exchange and killo bars for China and Indian market (min grade 99.5%) and Gold sold locally to Jewellers (min grade 99.8%). Values obtained from personal communication with Rand refinery and from Randy Refinery Corporate Brochure 2017.

exchanges.description:
It accounts for boht Unrefined Gold from South African mines and Unrefined Gold from non South African mines send to SA for refining. Values obtained from personal communication with Rand refinery are of: 0.509947871 kg/kg of refined gold produced and 0.509947871 kg/kg of refined gold produced respectively.


The original dataset included a minor input (0.0052129 kg) of scrap gold. However, due to a lack of such a product in the database, this exchange has not been included; instead, the amount has been added to this exchange (gold, unrefined) to ensure mass balance.
